ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned new frameworks through which to critically engage with media and other popular culture
Ideology, Interpellation, Coded and non-coded messages: a lot of theories through which to understand the way meaning is made subsconsciously. How racialization happens through these means
I learned the theoretical frameworks of the optics of race and critically analyzed the role of race in multisensory media.
How race is formed through visual media, how people can create coounter-ideologies by presenting images through the lens of historically marginalized communities, how to write a convincing argument
Close reading, conversation fascilitation
Learned about many of the important theories surrounding race and visual media, and learned many different ways of applying them when it comes to analyzing media!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths were the readings and explanations of the readings; I liked all the examples from present day used.
Interesting readings, thought provoking theories. Sometimes the content felt a bit dispersed and it would be nice to have tied the different parts of the course together more
The weekly assignment of comments on readings is relatively easy and the projects and papers are a great way to apply learned concepts.
Strengths" class was well facilated, reading material was AMAZING, time was slotted for students voices to be heard (through activities such as presentation)
class discussion, archived sources

Definite strength is professor el-tayeb! Shes literally so fantastic, she really brings just a really interesting perspective of European and specifically german racism. She is so keenly brilliant, but really doesnt make her students feel stupid when making comments, whereas a lot of yale professors just love to remind their students that they are dumb in comparison to them.

Strengths were that the discussion rarely dragged, that the final project can be whatever you want it to be (and I had a blast making mine), that more than half the grade is participation-based (and the Perusall comments led to a lively discussion), that the people are almost all smart and have intelligent things to say, and more. Weaknesses were that I don't think anybody really looked forward to coming to class each week, so a lot of it felt like we were going through the motions.
Wonderful syllabus selection, awesome class discussions, fun and exciting assignments, lots of creative freedom for students

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes
Yes for the concepts and methodology taught.
Love this class so much! Regardless of your major, you will learn so much from this course.
Yes, this is a class that will empower you to realize the importance of your voice and using it to contests forces of domination.
yes!
Yes! Professor El-Tayeb is amazing, the readings and class discussions are extremely interesting, and the course was really organized.
Yes absolutely. Professor el tayeb is amazing, all i wanted was for class to be longer, as it was about two hour class once a week!

No. This seminar feels like it should check off all of the boxes for an excellent class -- the material was interesting, the people knew what they were talking about, the class wasn't very hard. In spite of all of that, I didn't enjoy the class very much. I felt like I learned more about the topic the class was discussing when other classes I've taken have touched on this subject than I have in this class devoted to the subject. Our class discussions felt like a hodgepodge of whatever other ER&M classes people were actually thinking about brought into one class, which could be interesting at times, but didn't often feel like we were discussing the material. Professor El-Tayeb was a good seminar leader and had a good mix of letting people talk when we wanted to talk but contributing to the discussion in interesting ways when she spoke. I can't point to anything that I didn't like about this class, but it was far less than the sum of its parts.
Yes! Amazing social science course for anyone in a visual/performing arts related major, and just an awesome class overall!
